articles.headline: Managing a Child’s Allowance, the Online Version
articles.snippet: A look at some Web sites that aim to help children and their parents track chores, allowances, savings and spending — and maybe teach some financial literacy in the process.
articles.abstract: A look at some Web sites that aim to help children and their parents track chores, allowances, savings and spending — and maybe teach some financial literacy in the process.
articles.lead_paragraph: Giving children an allowance always seems like a good idea at first. But just try following through in practice.

articles.headline: As PC Sales Turn Down, Intel Trims Its Outlook
articles.snippet: Weak demand in growing markets like China affects the demand for computer chips.
articles.abstract: Weak demand in growing markets like China affects the demand for computer chips.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — With the personal computer market stalled, Intel, the primary maker of computer chips, warned its investors Friday that revenue would be lower than expected, as would profit margins.

articles.headline: Influence of Money Market Funds Ended Overhaul
articles.snippet: Opposition to proposals intended to prevent another financial panic puzzled the chairwoman of the Securities and Exchange Commission.
articles.abstract: Opposition to proposals intended to prevent another financial panic puzzled the chairwoman of the Securities and Exchange Commission.
articles.lead_paragraph: Four years after the fall of Lehman Brothers, and with a presidential campaign in full swing, everyone can surely agree on one thing: we shouldn’t risk another financial crisis.

articles.headline: Tiny Lifesaver for a Growing Worry
articles.snippet: Mylan, the maker of the epinephrine injector EpiPen, is expanding its marketing efforts in the face of new, competing devices and the surging rates of allergies in children.
articles.abstract: Mylan, the maker of the epinephrine injector EpiPen, is expanding its marketing efforts in the face of new, competing devices and the surging rates of allergies in children.
articles.lead_paragraph: It has become an all-too-familiar story in schools across the country: a child eats a peanut or is stung by a bee and suffers an immediate, life-threatening allergic reaction known as anaphylaxis.

articles.headline: A Day After the Party, It’s Still the Economy
articles.snippet: The disappointing jobs report leaves President Obama with fading hopes that the economy will surge before Election Day, straining his argument that he has put the country on the right path.
articles.abstract: The disappointing jobs report leaves President Obama with fading hopes that the economy will surge before Election Day, straining his argument that he has put the country on the right path.
articles.lead_paragraph: IOWA CITY — Only hours after accepting his party’s nomination for a second term, President Obama found himself on the defensive over a jobs report that was weak in almost every way.
articles.byline: By Helene Cooper and Annie Lowrey

articles.headline: Defying Canon and Civil Laws, Diocese Failed to Stop a Priest
articles.snippet: As recently as 2011, a bishop and Catholic officials in Kansas City, Mo., didn’t act to prevent a priest from taking pornographic photographs of young girls.
articles.abstract: As recently as 2011, a bishop and Catholic officials in Kansas City, Mo., didn’t act to prevent a priest from taking pornographic photographs of young girls.
articles.lead_paragraph: On the surface, the Rev. Shawn Ratigan was just the kind of dynamic new priest that any Roman Catholic bishop would have been happy to put in a parish. He rode a motorcycle, organized summer mission trips to Guatemala and joined Bishop Robert W. Finn and dozens of students on a bus trek to Washington for the “March for Life,” a big annual anti-abortion rally.

articles.headline: Unpredictable Danger Looms Close to the Heart
articles.snippet: Patients who received damaged defibrillator wires made by St. Jude Medical are learning that removing them can be risky, but so can leaving them in place.
articles.abstract: Patients who received damaged defibrillator wires made by St. Jude Medical are learning that removing them can be risky, but so can leaving them in place.
articles.lead_paragraph: Monsters attacked Avery de Groh when she was 4. That is how she remembers the day in 2007 when the defibrillator in her chest misfired, sending nine electric shocks through her body in less than 30 minutes.

articles.headline: In a Swirl of Excess, No Guilt Included
articles.snippet: It’s hard to tell the difference between the major political parties during convention week festivities.
articles.abstract: It’s hard to tell the difference between the major political parties during convention week festivities.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHARLOTTE, N.C.

articles.headline: Five Crucial Factors to Watch, Just 58 Days From the Election
articles.snippet: Two months before the election, President Obama and Mitt Romney agree on at least one thing: the collection of states where the race will be decided.
articles.abstract: Two months before the election, President Obama and Mitt Romney agree on at least one thing: the collection of states where the race will be decided.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Two months before the election, President Obama and Mitt Romney agree on one thing: the collection of states where the race will be decided.
articles.byline: By Jeff Zeleny and Jim Rutenberg

articles.headline: How to Find Weeds in a Mortgage Pool
articles.snippet: A computerized compendium of housing transactions could help investors identify the bad mortgages in many bundled securities.
articles.abstract: A computerized compendium of housing transactions could help investors identify the bad mortgages in many bundled securities.
articles.lead_paragraph: IT sounds like the Domesday Book of the housing bust. In fact, it is a computerized compendium of millions of housing transactions — a decade’s worth from across the country — that could finally help us get to the bottom of troubled mortgage investments.

articles.headline: Searching for a Speed Limit in High-Frequency Trading
articles.snippet: From their small brokerage firm, two men have led the fight against the surge of computer-driven, high-frequency trading on Wall Street.
articles.abstract: From their small brokerage firm, two men have led the fight against the surge of computer-driven, high-frequency trading on Wall Street.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHATHAM, N.J.

articles.headline: Game Maker Without a Rule Book
articles.snippet: Valve, the uncorporate but influential video game company, thinks it may be onto the next big thing in games: wearable computing.
articles.abstract: Valve, the uncorporate but influential video game company, thinks it may be onto the next big thing in games: wearable computing.
articles.lead_paragraph: BELLEVUE, Wash.

articles.headline: Debt Collectors Cashing In on Student Loans
articles.snippet: In 2011 the Department of Education paid $1.4 billion to collection agencies to find defaulters, a group that includes nearly one in six borrowers with a balance.
articles.abstract: In 2011 the Department of Education paid $1.4 billion to collection agencies to find defaulters, a group that includes nearly one in six borrowers with a balance.
articles.lead_paragraph: At a protest last year at New York University, students called attention to their mounting debt by wearing T-shirts with the amount they owed scribbled across the front — $90,000, $75,000, $20,000.

articles.headline: Potential for a Mining Boom Splits Factions in Afghanistan
articles.snippet: With a trillion-dollar cache of oil, gold and other resources underground, hopes of self-sufficiency in Afghanistan are tempered by worries about corruption and security.
articles.abstract: With a trillion-dollar cache of oil, gold and other resources underground, hopes of self-sufficiency in Afghanistan are tempered by worries about corruption and security.
articles.lead_paragraph: KALU VALLEY, Afghanistan — If there is a road to a happy ending in Afghanistan, much of the path may run underground: in the trillion-dollar reservoir of natural resources — oil, gold, iron ore, copper, lithium and other minerals — that has brought hopes of a more self-sufficient country, if only the wealth can be wrested from blood-soaked soil.

articles.headline: Construction and Real Estate Hinder China’s Growth
articles.snippet: Investment in new buildings and other fixed assets, once a mainstay of the nation’s economy, grew at the second-lowest pace since 2002.
articles.abstract: Investment in new buildings and other fixed assets, once a mainstay of the nation’s economy, grew at the second-lowest pace since 2002.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHENGDU, China — With more than 100 tall cranes on the skyline, this metropolis in western China looks vibrant at first glance despite the country’s sharp economic slowdown.

articles.headline: Europe Plan Faces Threat in Germany
articles.snippet: On Wednesday, the work of the European Central Bank could be undone in a stroke by judges in Germany, who have the power to block the country from contributing to the European rescue fund.
articles.abstract: On Wednesday, the work of the European Central Bank could be undone in a stroke by judges in Germany, who have the power to block the country from contributing to the European rescue fund.
articles.lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT — With a few choice words last week, the European Central Bank and its president, Mario Draghi, managed to tame bond markets and inspire a market rally. But the coming week may reveal whether the rescue plan for Spain and Italy was a turning point in the euro zone crisis or just a short-lived spell of relief.
articles.byline: By Jack Ewing and Melissa Eddy

articles.headline: Death Sentence for a Top Iraqi Leader in a Day of Bloodshed
articles.snippet: Tariq al-Hashimi, the Iraqi vice president accused of commanding sectarian death squads, was sentenced hours after a wave of attacks that claimed at least 100 lives.
articles.abstract: Tariq al-Hashimi, the Iraqi vice president accused of commanding sectarian death squads, was sentenced hours after a wave of attacks that claimed at least 100 lives.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD — A vice president of Iraq, a prominent Sunni Muslim, was convicted of murder and sentenced to death on Sunday in a trial conducted in absentia. The verdict coincided with a wave of bombings and insurgent attacks that claimed at least 100 lives, making Sunday one of the bloodiest days in Iraq since American troops withdrew last year.
articles.byline: By Omar Al-Jawoshy and Michael Schwirtz

articles.headline: Innovation in Journalism Goes Begging for Support
articles.snippet: Despite receiving positive press attention, Homicide Watch, the Web site that tracked every murder in Washington D.C., is on hiatus and seeking funds to continue.
articles.abstract: Despite receiving positive press attention, Homicide Watch, the Web site that tracked every murder in Washington D.C., is on hiatus and seeking funds to continue.
articles.lead_paragraph: Journalism has a shortage of many things: capital, advertisers and, in some instances, readers. But certainly its most precious commodity is innovation.

articles.headline: Treasury to Cut A.I.G. Stake Below 50%
articles.snippet: The Treasury Department said on Sunday that it planned to sell an additional $18 billion worth of shares in the American International Group, drastically reducing the government’s stake in the bailed-out insurer.
articles.abstract: The Treasury Department said on Sunday that it planned to sell an additional $18 billion worth of shares in the American International Group, drastically reducing the government’s stake in the bailed-out insurer.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Treasury Department said on Sunday that it was planning its biggest sale of shares in the American International Group to date, making the federal government a minority shareholder in the bailed-out insurer for the first time since it took control of the company four years ago.
articles.byline: By Michael J. de la Merced

articles.headline: To Smuggle More Drugs, Traffickers Go Under the Sea
articles.snippet: American authorities have discovered models of a new drug-ferrying submarine capable of traveling, unseen from the surface, from Ecuador to Los Angeles.
articles.abstract: American authorities have discovered models of a new drug-ferrying submarine capable of traveling, unseen from the surface, from Ecuador to Los Angeles.
articles.lead_paragraph: KEY WEST, Fla. — For more than 24 hours last September, a Coast Guard helicopter and speedboat pursued drug traffickers and their contraband across the Caribbean Sea. Finally they caught up with the improbable vessel, the latest innovation in the decades-old drug war. It was a submarine.
articles.byline: By Michael S. Schmidt and Thom Shanker

articles.headline: Google Struggles to Unseat Amazon as the Web’s Most Popular Mall
articles.snippet: As it inches into e-commerce, Google is now charging retailers to appear on its site, a move it says will improve product listings.
articles.abstract: As it inches into e-commerce, Google is now charging retailers to appear on its site, a move it says will improve product listings.
articles.lead_paragraph: Whether you are looking to buy a power tool or neon jeans online, chances are you start your search on Google or Amazon.com. But which one?
articles.byline: By Claire Cain Miller and Stephanie Clifford

articles.headline: Romney’s Tax Plan Leaves Key Variables Blank
articles.snippet: Mitt Romney has pledged to cut individual income tax rates for everyone, but he has provided few specifics, confounding analysts and leaving himself open to attack from Democrats.
articles.abstract: Mitt Romney has pledged to cut individual income tax rates for everyone, but he has provided few specifics, confounding analysts and leaving himself open to attack from Democrats.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — If any single question can be said to dominate the presidential campaign, it is whether the conservative policies advocated by Mitt Romney would help or hurt the middle class. And no issue hits the heart of that question more than taxes.
articles.byline: By Annie Lowrey and David Kocieniewski

articles.headline: On Campus, an Experiment to Save Local News
articles.snippet: Mercer University is undertaking a $5.6 million project, which partners student work with news organizations in the area, in the hopes of reviving local journalism.
articles.abstract: Mercer University is undertaking a $5.6 million project, which partners student work with news organizations in the area, in the hopes of reviving local journalism.
articles.lead_paragraph: MACON, Ga. — From the rattling cicadas at twilight to the willow trees bending in the late summer heat, the lush campus of Mercer University seems like the last place to find one of the nation’s boldest journalism experiments.

articles.headline: A Tight Election May Be Tangled in Legal Battles
articles.snippet: With federal and state courts handing down decisions on ballot casting and counting, the presidential election may hinge partly on last-minute legal battles by both parties.
articles.abstract: With federal and state courts handing down decisions on ballot casting and counting, the presidential election may hinge partly on last-minute legal battles by both parties.
articles.lead_paragraph: The November presidential election, widely expected to rest on a final blitz of advertising and furious campaigning, may also hinge nearly as much on last-minute legal battles over when and how ballots should be cast and counted, particularly if the race remains tight in battleground states.

articles.headline: Fighting for Bangladesh Labor, and Ending Up in Pauper’s Grave
articles.snippet: The murder of a labor organizer bore a grim familiarity in a country with a brutal legacy of politically motivated killings.
articles.abstract: The murder of a labor organizer bore a grim familiarity in a country with a brutal legacy of politically motivated killings.
articles.lead_paragraph: ASHULIA, Bangladesh — His tiny office was lost among the hulking garment factories that churn out cargo pants or polo shirts for brands like Gap or Tommy Hilfiger, yet workers managed to find Aminul Islam. They came with problems. Unpaid wages. Abusive bosses. Mr. Islam, a labor organizer, fought for their rights.

articles.headline: Communist Leader’s Absence Sets Off Rumor Mills in China
articles.snippet: Speculation intensified over the whereabouts of Xi Jinping, China’s presumptive new president, who has been missing from public view in recent days.
articles.abstract: Speculation intensified over the whereabouts of Xi Jinping, China’s presumptive new president, who has been missing from public view in recent days.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIJING — The strange disappearance from public view of China’s presumptive new leader is turning a year that was supposed to showcase the Communist Party’s stability into something of an annus horribilis.
